Award.AwardTitle: Hypergraphs, Ramsey Theory and Extremal Combinatorics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research concentrates mainly on problems in Ramsey theory and on extremal graph and hypergraph theory. Both of these areas belong to the mainstream of contemporary discrete mathematics and are often motivated by applications in other areas, such as theoretical computer science. In tackling these problems, a variety of combinatorial methods will be used, such as probabilistic methods and applications of regularity techniques. The PI also plans to develop new techniques leading to the construction of graphs with certain special properties. The Ramsey type problems suggested in the proposal include the investigation of the asymptotic behavior of hypergraph Ramsey numbers, of induced Ramsey numbers, of size-Ramsey numbers, as well of the Erdos-Rogers function. The PI also intends to study some problems in structural Ramsey theory. The extremal problems that the PI intends to investigate include Ramsey-Tur√°n problems and the study of Hamilton cycles and matchings in hypergraphs, as well as extremal problems regarding random subsets of integers.

This research will serve as a basis for the mentoring activities of the PI. Concepts and questions of combinatorial character appear naturally in other branches of mathematics and, more broadly speaking, in computer science and in the physical, biological, and social sciences, making combinatorial mathematics of interest not only within mathematics itself, but within the sciences as a whole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PI conducted research in several areas of extremal and probabilistic combinatorics. Most ofthe problems concerned the study of hypergraphs, with focus on questions in Ramsey theory and extremalcombinatorics. The PI has been actively engaged in developing methods involving quasirandomness,investigating relations between various concepts of quasirandomness and broadening their applicability.Specific areas in which the PI worked include Ramsey theory, extremal problems on matchings andHamilton cycles in hypergraphs as well as the study of random and pseudorandom objects. The research lead to more than 50 publications (published or accepted for publication), many of which appeared in the best journals in combinatorics and some works appeared in general mathematics journals (including Journal of the European Mathematical Society, International Mathematics Research Notices, and the journals of the London Mathematical Society).
Substantial part of the research concerned extremal problems for hypergraphs. Given a hypergraph F we are interested in the maximum density (so-called Turan density of F) that a large hypergraph H containing no copy of F can have. Maybe the most prominent basic problem in that area is the longstanding 5/9-conjecture of Turan (promoted by Erdos), which asserts that the Turan density of the complete 3-uniform hypergraph on four vertices is 5/9. This conjecture dates back to the work of Turán in 1941 and despite of considerable effort since then, this problem and the determination of Turan densities for hypergraphs in general seems to be still out of reach.
The PI investigated a variant of the classical problem by imposing additional restrictions on the distribution of the hyperedges of the large hypergraph H. Roughly speaking, we considered uniformly dense hypergraphs, i.e., hypergraphs which induce on large sets of vertices at least a given edge density. This lead to many interesting and more manageable subproblems, some of which were already considered by Erdos and Sos more than 30 years ago. In joint work with Reiher and Schacht the PI developed an approach for these problems based on the regularity method of hypergraphs, which enabled the use tools for quasirandom hypergraphs for these problems. This work lead to a series of papers and may hopefully be a first step to a more systematic study of these intriguing problems.
The work of the PI was recognised within the mathematical community, when he was invited to deliver a plenary talk at the International Congress of Mathematicians in Seoul in 2014. The project gave ample opportunity for current and former PhD-students to engage in research on central problems in extremal and probabilistic combinatorics and to start their own respective academic careers under the guidance of the PI. In fact, four PhD-students advised by the PI received the PhDs during the grant period and more than two-thirds of the submitted publications were joint with current and former PhD-students of the PI.
